newsitem.title: ISRAEL: ECI Telecom optimistic about China deal.
newsitem.headline: ECI Telecom optimistic about China deal.

text.p: Chinese Vice-Premier Li Lanqing's tour on Wednesday of an ECI Telecom plant raised hopes at the Israeli telecommunications company for a long-awaited $60 million contract with China's Ji Tong Communications Co.

"The fact that this visit has taken place here...I think we have reason to be optimistic," ECI President and CEO David Rubner told reporters at the inauguration of the plant, which was designed to fulfill the contract.
He added: "I cannot under any circumstances give you any dates or deadlines because the things are not in my control".
China is among ECI's top 10 markets. "It's not our largest market at the moment but it definitely has one of the largest potentials," Rubner said.

ECI and China's Ji Tong Communications Co signed a cooperation agreement in September 1995 under which ECI would supply a complete network for customs information processing and foreign trade transactions.
The contract is subject to Chinese government approval.
"There are some government approvals that still have to be obtained, or maybe they have been obtained and we have not been notified," Rubner said.
"You have to arm yourself with a lot of patience in order to do business with China."
He said the contract would run for three years. The Ofakim plant was built in five months and began production in October 1996.
Commenting to reporters later, Li said Israel and China should work together.
"I think if we join our efforts we can create a very, very strong competition force," Li said.

Chinese Vice-Minister of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Liu Shanzai said in formal remarks: "I also hope this ECI factory produces high quality, high level products that are going to be used by China's Golden Bridge project".
ECI's business with China doubled from 1995 to 1996, reaching $27.5 million last year compared to $14 million in 1995, Rubner said. Volume in 1994 was similar to that in 1995.
"It has grown very nicely...before 1994 it was a question of one or two million dollars," Rubner said.
Rubner said ECI accounts for 40 percent of total Israeli exports to China, a market it entered in the 1980s before ties were established between China and Israel in 1992.
